standard_metadata.standard_description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

hints.content: $6 \times 36$ and $0.6 \times 0.36$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $6 \times 36$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.6 \times 0.36$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.6\times 0.36$.  $\begin{align} 0.6 \times 0.36 &\approx 0.6\times 0.4\\\\ \phantom{0.6 \times 0.36} &\approx \dfrac6{10}\times \dfrac4{10}\\\\ \phantom{0.6 \times 0.36} &\approx \dfrac{24}{100}\\\\ &\approx 0.24 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $216$ to get a product close to $0.24$?

$4 \times 62$ and $0.4 \times 0.62$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $4 \times 62$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.4 \times 0.62 $.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.4 \times 0.62$.  $\begin{align} 0.4 \times 0.62 &\approx 0.4 \times 0.6\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{4}{10}\times \dfrac{6}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{24}{100}\\\\ &\approx 0.24 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $248$ to get a product close to $0.24$?

$9 \times 35$ and $0.9 \times 0.35$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $9 \times 35$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.9 \times 0.35 $.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.9 \times 0.35$.  $\begin{align} 0.9 \times 0.35 &\approx 0.9 \times 0.4\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{9}{10}\times \dfrac{4}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{36}{100}\\\\ &\approx 0.36 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $315$ to get a product close to $0.36$?

$43 \times 8$ and $0.43 \times 0.8$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $43 \times 8$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.43 \times 0.8$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.43 \times 0.8$.  $\begin{align} 0.43 \times 0.8 &\approx 0.4 \times 0.8\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{4}{10}\times \dfrac{8}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{32}{100}\\\\ &\approx 0.32 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $344$ to get a product close to $0.32$?

$82 \times 3$ and $0.82 \times 0.3$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $82 \times 3$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.82 \times 0.3$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.82 \times 0.3$.  $\begin{align} 0.82 \times 0.3 &\approx 0.8 \times 0.3\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{8}{10}\times \dfrac{3}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{24}{100}\\\\ &\approx 0.24 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $246$ to get a product close to $0.24$?

$27 \times 7$ and $0.27 \times 0.7$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $27 \times 7$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.27 \times 0.7$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.27 \times 0.7$.  $\begin{align} 0.27 \times 0.7 &\approx 0.3 \times 0.7\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{3}{10}\times \dfrac{7}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{21}{100}\\\\ &\approx 0.21 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $189$ to get a product close to $0.21$?

$11 \times 98$ and $1.1 \times 0.98$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $11 \times 98$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $1.1 \times 0.98$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $1.1 \times 0.98$.  $\begin{align} 1.1 \times 0.98 &\approx 1 \times 1\\\\ &\approx 1 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $1078$ to get a product close to $1$?

$35 \times 21$ and $3.5 \times 0.21$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $35 \times 21$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $3.5 \times 0.21$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $3.5 \times 0.21$.  $\begin{align} 3.5 \times 0.21 &\approx 4 \times 0.2\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{4}{1}\times \dfrac{2}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{8}{10}\\\\ &\approx 0.8 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $735$ to get a product close to $0.8$?

$28 \times 72$ and $2.8 \times 0.72$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $28 \times 72$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $2.8 \times 0.72$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $2.8 \times 0.72$.  $\begin{align} 2.8 \times 0.72 &\approx 3 \times 0.7\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{3}{1}\times \dfrac{7}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{21}{10}\\\\ &\approx 2.1 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $2016$ to get a product close to $2.1$?

$12 \times 81$ and $0.12 \times 8.1$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $12 \times 81$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.12 \times 8.1$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.12 \times 8.1$.  $\begin{align} 0.12 \times 8.1 &\approx 0.1 \times 8\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{1}{10}\times \dfrac{8}{1}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{8}{10}\\\\ &\approx 0.8 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $972$ to get a product close to $0.8$?

$51 \times 34$ and $0.51 \times 3.4$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $51 \times 34$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.51 \times 3.4$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.51 \times 3.4$.  $\begin{align} 0.51 \times 3.4 &\approx 0.5 \times 3\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{1}{2}\times \dfrac{3}{1}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{3}{2}\\\\ &\approx 1.5 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $1734$ to get a product close to $1.5$?

$31 \times 42$ and $0.31 \times 4.2$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $31 \times 42$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.31 \times 4.2$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.31 \times 4.2$.  $\begin{align} 0.31 \times 4.2 &\approx 0.3 \times 4\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{3}{10}\times \dfrac{4}{1}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{12}{10}\\\\ &\approx 1.2 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $1302$ to get a product close to $1.2$?

$69 \times 2$ and $6.9 \times 0.2$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $69 \times 2$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $6.9 \times 0.2$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $6.9 \times 0.2$.  $\begin{align} 6.9 \times 0.2 &\approx 7 \times 0.2\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{7}{1}\times \dfrac{2}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{14}{10}\\\\ &\approx 1.4 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $138$ to get a product close to $1.4$?

$77 \times 7$ and $7.7 \times 0.7$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $77 \times 7$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $7.7 \times 0.7$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $7.7 \times 0.7$.  $\begin{align} 7.7 \times 0.7 &\approx 8 \times 0.7\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{8}{1}\times \dfrac{7}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{56}{10}\\\\ &\approx 5.6 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $539$ to get a product close to $5.6$?

$49 \times 3$ and $4.9 \times 0.3$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $49 \times 3$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $4.9 \times 0.3$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $4.9 \times 0.3$.  $\begin{align} 4.9 \times 0.3 &\approx 5 \times 0.3\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{5}{1}\times \dfrac{3}{10}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{15}{10}\\\\ &\approx 1.5 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $147$ to get a product close to $1.5$?

$8 \times 44$ and $0.8 \times 4.4$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $8 \times 44$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.8 \times 4.4$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.8 \times 4.4$.  $\begin{align} 0.8 \times 4.4 &\approx 0.8 \times 4\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{8}{10}\times \dfrac{4}{1}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{32}{10}\\\\ &\approx 3.2 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $352$ to get a product close to $3.2$?

$5 \times 33$ and $0.5 \times 3.3$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $5 \times 33$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.5 \times 3.3$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.5 \times 3.3$.  $\begin{align} 0.5 \times 3.3 &\approx 0.5 \times 3\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{1}{2}\times \dfrac{3}{1}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{3}{2}\\\\ &\approx 1.5 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $165$ to get a product close to $1.5$?

$3 \times 42$ and $0.3 \times 4.2$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $3 \times 42$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $0.3 \times 4.2$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $0.3 \times 4.2$.  $\begin{align} 0.3 \times 4.2 &\approx 0.3 \times 4\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{3}{10}\times \dfrac{4}{1}\\\\ &\approx \dfrac{12}{10}\\\\ &\approx 1.2 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $126$ to get a product close to $1.2$?

$34 \times 61$ and $3.4 \times 6.1$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $34 \times 61$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $3.4 \times 6.1$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $3.4 \times 6.1$.  $\begin{align} 3.4 \times 6.1 &\approx 3 \times 6\\\\ &\approx 18 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $2074$ to get a product close to $18$?

$12 \times 77$ and $1.2 \times 7.7$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $12 \times 77$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $1.2 \times 7.7$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $1.2 \times 7.7$.  $\begin{align} 1.2 \times 7.7 &\approx 1 \times 8\\\\ &\approx 8 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $924$ to get a product close to $8$?

$59 \times 33$ and $5.9 \times 3.3$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $59 \times 33$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $5.9 \times 3.3$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $5.9 \times 3.3$.  $\begin{align} 5.9 \times 3.3 &\approx 6 \times 3\\\\ &\approx 18 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $1947$ to get a product close to $18$?

$11 \times 76$ and $1.1 \times 7.6$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $11 \times 76$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $1.1 \times 7.6$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $1.1 \times 7.6$.  $\begin{align} 1.1 \times 7.6 &\approx 1 \times 8\\\\ &\approx 8 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $836$ to get a product close to $8$?

$31 \times 34$ and $3.1 \times 3.4$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $31 \times 34$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $3.1 \times 3.4$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $3.1 \times 3.4$.  $\begin{align} 3.1 \times 3.4 &\approx 3 \times 3\\\\ &\approx 9 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $1054$ to get a product close to $9$?

$53 \times 82$ and $5.3 \times 8.2$ multiply the same digits in the same order.    So, the product of both problems will also have the same digits in the same order.   Let's multiply $53 \times 82$.  Then we can estimate to place the decimal point in the product of $5.3 \times 8.2$.

Let's estimate to place the decimal in $5.3 \times 8.2$.  $\begin{align} 5.3 \times 8.2 &\approx 5 \times 8\\\\ &\approx 40 \end{align}$  Where can we place the decimal in $4346$ to get a product close to $40$?
